structured_info.title_cn: 复杂系统的协同设计：从自主性到未来移动系统
structured_info.title_en: Co-Design of Complex Systems: From Autonomy to Future Mobility Systems
structured_info.abstract: The contemporary era struggles with the intricate challenge of designing complex systems characterized by intricate webs of interactions. This thesis focuses on the theory of co-design, extending from designing individual platforms like autonomous vehicles to orchestrating entire mobility systems. It establishes a monotone theory of co-design using category theory to elucidate compositionality and functorial solution schemes, providing both theoretical foundations and practical guidance for real-world applications in embodied intelligence.
structured_info.methodology: Develops a monotone theory of co-design leveraging category theory; formalizes design problems as mathematical structures; employs composition operations (series, parallel, feedback); implements solution schemes through functorial mappings; validates via case studies in autonomy and mobility systems.
structured_info.conclusion: Provides a robust mathematical framework for co-design enabling efficient computation of optimal solutions; demonstrates applicability across autonomy and mobility domains; establishes compositionality as fundamental for handling system complexity; opens avenues for future extensions in modeling strategic interactions.

analysis.Overview: Presents a mathematical framework for co-designing complex systems using category theory, addressing challenges in autonomy and mobility through compositional methods and monotonicity principles.
Background_and_Motivation: Urbanization growth and sustainability demands create urgency for efficient transportation systems; complexity arises from interdependent hardware/software components and socio-technical interactions.
Solve simultaneous optimization of heterogeneous system components while satisfying constraints and multi-objective requirements.
Cites urbanization statistics (55%→68% by 2050), mobility service growth (1000% in NYC), and sustainability imperatives (EU's 90% emission reduction target) to establish urgency.
Links specific co-design challenges to broader urban sustainability goals through energy/emission data and mobility inefficiencies.
Systems Engineering, Applied Mathematics, Transportation Science, and Robotics.
Conceptual_Framework_and_Innovations: Co-design: Simultaneous selection of heterogeneous components under system constraints; Monotonicity: Order-preserving properties in design spaces; Compositionality: Hierarchical system construction via interconnected components.
Monotonicity enables efficient optimization; compositionality connects component-level design to system-level objectives through category theory morphisms.
Design problems exhibit order structures; component interactions follow compositional rules; real-world constraints are mathematically representable.
Introduces novel categorical formalization of co-design; advances solution schemes for interconnected systems; bridges theoretical math with practical engineering.
Methodology: Category theory constructs design spaces; monotone mappings formalize feasibility; series/parallel/feedback compositions build systems; functorial approaches compute solutions.
Novelty: First categorical framework for co-design; applicability: Validated in AV/mobility case studies; rationality: Aligns with physics-based constraints and optimization theory.
Case studies use domain-specific parameters (e.g., vehicle dynamics, urban demand); preprocessing includes functional decomposition; representativeness evidenced by real-world mobility challenges.
Rigorous poset/lattice foundations; evaluation via optimality proofs and task-specific metrics (e.g., energy vs. errors).
Follows formal methods paradigm; category theory enables abstraction but constrains modeling to compositional structures.
Results: Theoretical: Co-design category (DP) with monoidal/traced properties; Practical: Optimal solutions for AV/mobility case studies.
Significance: Unifies disjointed design approaches; reliability: Mathematically proven monotonicity; stability: Handles feedback via fixed-point methods.
Argumentation_and_Logic: Hierarchical: Background → Theory → Composition → Solving → Applications.
1) Formalize design problems 2) Establish monotonicity 3) Define compositions 4) Solve via functors 5) Validate with case studies.
Strength: Rigorous categorical proofs; weakness: Abstract formalism; counters via concrete mobility examples.
Strengths_and_Limitations: Unified cross-domain framework; computational tractability; vertical/horizontal compositionality.
Assumes monotonicity; limited non-compositional interactions; scalability unverified for ultra-large systems.
Category theory focus may overlook non-compositional system aspects; optimization confined to predefined posets.
Academic_Discourse_and_Rhetoric: Advances 'automated design' discourse via mathematical formalization; positions as bridge between theory/practice.
Technical: 'Functorial solution schemes', 'monoidal categories'; persuasive: Urgency framing with urbanization data; authority-building through Simon's design philosophy citations.
Strategic citations of Nobel laureates (Simon) and advisors; establishes legitimacy in robotics/control communities.
Conclusions_and_Implications: Co-design requires compositional mathematics; category theory enables efficient optimization; framework generalizes across autonomy/mobility domains.
Extend to strategic interactions (game theory); improve non-monotonic handling; apply to energy-grid integration.
